Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Quantifying genetic and ecological variation to delimit species in Hawaiian Pritchardia (Palmae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Species delimitations are essential to many aspects of evolutionary biology, including systematics, conservation, and ecology. The goals of this research project are to test species delimitations in Hawaiian Pritchardia plants with molecular and ecological data, and to interpret the history of colonization and subsequent expansion of Pritchardia, one of the most species-rich plant genera in Hawaii. Pritchardia (Palmae) is an exceptional study system because of its economic importance, high endemism, number of endangered species, and numerous poorly understood species complexes. It is also a conservation priority for native species in the United States. Data from species ranges and habitats will add to baseline information on species that are included in the Plant Extinction Prevention Program of the State of Hawaii.

Results from this study will provide critical data for conservation efforts and will be published and reported to rare plant conservation and management groups and the Department of Land and Natural Resources. Pritchardia is the seventh largest plant genus in Hawaii and this study will provide further evaluation of ongoing comparative studies including patterns of endangerment, speciation, and colonization. This research will also serve as a basis for a collaborative taxonomic revision of Pritchardia species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Species delimitations are essential to many aspects of evolutionary biology, including systematics, conservation, and ecology. A new emphasis has been put on species delimitation, at least in part because of growing concerns over threats to biodiversity. Our study resulted in important conclusions about 1) the use of molecular and morphological data to rigorously delimit independent lineages as separate species and 2) the use of species delimitations and relationships to interpret the history of colonization and subsequent expansion of eastern Pacific Pritchardia (loulu palms). This award enabled us to infer the process of diversification of these Hawaiian palms, including hybridization between species.      

Results from this study were presented at national (Smithsonian Institution Symposium on the Evolution of Life on Pacific Islands and Reefs: Past, Present, and Future; Honolulu, Hawaii, May 2011) and international (International Botanical Congress, Melbourne, Australia, August 2011) scientific meetings. Results synthesizing evolutionary drivers of island radiation in the tribe that includes Pritchardia were submitted for publication to Systematic Biology. DNA markers were developed through international collaboration (Bacon et al., 2011) and species-delimitation results are in preparation for submission to BMC Biology. Our results also provide baseline data for conservation efforts and a forthcoming collaborative revision of Pritchardia species (Bacon and Hodel, in preparation).

The broader impacts from this award include planned updates to Pritchardia species on the Smithsonian’s Flora of the Hawaiian Islands website (http://botany.si.edu/pacificislandbiodiversity/hawaiianflora/index.htm). International collaboration was an important factor of this award through joint research with Dr. Harald Meimberg (University of Porto, Portugal) on the development and optimization of DNA microsatellite markers for Pritchardia. Two undergraduates involved in this project were trained in molecular techniques and general phylogenetic-analysis methods. In addition to co-authoring publications that resulted from their work, undergraduate students presented their results at the annual Colorado State University Undergraduate Research and Creativity Symposium. Lastly, collections for this project augmented the Herbarium Pacificum at the Bishop Museum, which is focused on Pacific flora.
